We wrapped up a highly successful first week of school and we are onto the second week now. We feel that our kids were the source of our success last week. They should up with their own personal masks and willingly wore them. It was obvious to us that you had conversations with them of the significance of wearing masks. We learned so much about our current plans and systems when the entire district was in remote learning mode and we have made some adjustments in preparation for this Wednesday. One of those adjustments is the need for all 6-12 distance learning students need to bring their charged chromebook to school as you will use your device to test on. Specifically, all kids will be home for learning except the students who are currently home. Those students showed up to take the math test last week and we need the same set of students for the reading test this week. School busses will run their routes for Wednesday pickup for distant learning students who need transportation to school on Wednesday.

Message from the Superintendent:
The leadership at CISD have worked to develop a protocol for what we will do in case someone in our organization has the virus. Part of that protocol was notification of all staff and CISD staff and parents. We have just received word of a confirmed case of Coronavirus in CISD. The case is that of a student who has not exhibited any symptoms and was only tested as a result of the parents testing positive. The student tested last Thursday and is currently quarantined. The student will only be allowed to return to school and/or its activities once the student has been cleared by the doctor. For any and all questions you will need to reply only to me.
kward@clarksvilleisd.org

Rest assured that your concerns matter to me and I am committed to being a listener right now. I, and the rest of the CISD leadership will continue to monitor this and any other situations.

The District plans to send this information out via School Messenger so parents can expect a phone message.

Pandemic Electronic Benefit Transfer (P-EBT) is a one-time food benefit for families who lost access to free or reduced-price meals due to school closures. Eligible P-EBT families will receive application instructions from schools in late May. The P-EBT application will open the first week of June.
P-EBT food benefits are for children who received SNAP food benefits for March 2020 and children who are certified for free or reduced-price school meals during the 2019-20 Texas school year. For more information, visit: hhs.texas.gov/PEBT

Brenda Hunter is with Annette Daniels Hobbs.
September 6, 2019 at 1:41 AM ·

Wow!! What a day we had. Clarksville High School held its first Career Fair for students 8th thru 12th grades. Mrs. Annette Hobbs, our Career, College and Military Readiness Coach planned and implemented this awesome event. As we embrace new pathways students are being prepared to exit school with soft and hard skills; college readiness skills; guidance in the selection of career choices etc. Careers featured: EMT, Nursing, Teaching, HVAC, Military, X-Ray Tech. Representatives from PJC spoke about all the career choices offered at PJC. Currently we have 11 students traveling to PJC enrolled in PJC Welding program. Dr. Phillips expressed that we had some students in Instructional Practices to become teachers. Mr.Ward, our Superintendent shared words of expectations as we journey into CISD new Career Pathways. It truly was a great day for our students.

CHRISTUS St. Michael is with Carla Roadcap.
June 18, 2019 at 11:20 AM ·

CHRISTUS St. Michael Health System awarded health and wellness grants totaling $45,000 to 22 area Texas schools! Schools receiving grants have participated in the free Mobile Pediatric Asthma Program for school-aged children during the 2018-2019 school term.

Areas schools receiving grants include: Bloomburg, Clarksville, Malta, McLeod, Mt. Vernon, Simms, Hooks, Maud, Linden-Kildare, Texarkana, Redwater, Red Lick, Queen City, Avery, Atlanta, Liberty-Eylau, Hughes Springs, New Boston, Daingerfield, Pleasant Grove, DeKalb, and Jefferson.

Provided by CHRISTUS St. Michael Health System in conjunction with Genesis PrimeCare, the Mobile Pediatric Asthma Program, only one of two in the state of Texas, offers asthma screenings and evaluations at no charge to participants. In addition to asthma screenings, the CHRISTUS St. Michael Mobile Asthma Program provides services such as breathing tests, personal asthma management plans, parent and child education as well as follow-up care.
